A friendly reminder that a Port Byron education is for Port Byron residents. Therefore to enroll a student you need to live in the district.

At the time of registration, please bring the following documents:

Documentation demonstrating proof of age (such as a birth certificate, immunization records, passport, or immigration paperwork).
Custody paper showing parental custody, if applicable.
Proof of residency, defined as a rental or mortgage agreement or utility bill showing your physical address. These are the only items acceptable.
If the person registering a student is not the parent, the adult must show court papers proving they have custody of the child.

A couple of residents have voiced concerns on the mail only balloting for school budget and board of education this year.

The decision to only have balloting done exclusively by mail was the governor‚Äôs. We are left to make the best of this situation and ensure we do it well.

The ballots will be collected by election officials who are not employees of the district. The first stage is to make sure that the ballots are legal. The person doing this will not open the envelope to see the ballot, but simply check on the validity of the signature.

A second official will take the pile of envelopes and open them and place the ballots in a box to be shuffled before proceeding to the last stage, which is completed by a third official.

This official will run them through the machine. The machine will count them just like a regular election.

School personnel will not be counting ballots. In addition, the process will ensure no one person completes the three stages. This will maintain privacy.

Day 35

Tomorrow begins another week and a new day to distribute meals to students. We are still shooting for 1500 meals for the week. We have come close the past two weeks.

We have enjoyed sharing with you the stories of students and teachers discussing our online learning program. There are more to come this week. We have to be honest that some of the youngest students are beyond adorable.

The one constant in the articles regardless of age is the personal touch. Online learning works best when parents provide support in the home and teachers have the opportunity to provide personal communication with the learner. We know from lots of data or metrics that we are performing at an amazing level at this juncture. But, in reality, we simply know from the smiles. That is what we hear and see in the anecdotes.

While we enjoy remarkable success, we have not 'rested on our laurels'. Both buildings are working to increase student engagement this week. We will share their stories in subsequent posts.

Take care and be safe,

- Nightly cleanings include wiping down the most frequently-touched items in classrooms
- Switching nightly cleaning product to more of a disinfecting cleaning product
- Installing a dispenser for a disinfecting product at the bus garage, so that buses can be disinfected via garden sprayer

We‚Äôve also made great use of our ‚Äúflu killer‚Äù machine, which helps our staff spray both the top and bottom of desks and chairs to help better eliminate germs.

Most importantly, we have a diligent and dedicated staff that‚Äôs taking health threats like these very seriously, and are doing everything they can to make Port Byron as clean and safe for students and faculty.

Last week, students in Mrs. Kanuck‚Äôs Global Studies 10 class were transported to a time and place considerably different than modern day Port Byron. With the help of the CNYRIC‚Äôs Mike Dingman, students strapped on virtual reality headsets and took a simulated tour of the Industrial Revolution!

Mrs. Kanuck guided the tour from her tablet, while students explored the 360-degree simulated space, using their remote to lock onto (and discover more about) objects of interest. It was easy to see how lost the students became in this world, to the point where everyone in physical reality was looking in completely different directions, exploring the virtual world around them!

Following the virtual tour of the time period, students pulled out their Chromebooks to answer questions in real time about what they had just learned. It was a remarkable show of just how far virtual reality has come, while serving as a perfect example of how history (and education at large) can be transformed through the use of technology, relative to what could be accomplished even a decade prior.

Dana West‚Äôs ‚ÄúHistory of Technology‚Äù class traces the impact of technological development on the growth of agriculture, communication, construction, warfare, medicine, transportation and manufacturing over the decades.

Recently, several students from the class paid a visit Fort Ontario in Oswego, where they saw some of these advancements firsthand. Students learned all about the construction of the fort, and some of the defining features that made it easier to defend.

Later, the class traveled to the Ward O'Hara Agricultural Museum in Auburn, where they took a look at the collection of early plows, harvesters and combined harvester/threshers that served as the foundation for today's combines. They also learned about Auburn‚Äôs manufacturing history in Auburn, and how it was specifically geared toward agriculture.

The visits served as a wrap-up to some of the units that had been covered in class to start the year, giving students a true hands-on look at the history they‚Äôve been reading about. Check out some of the photos below, taken by students during the field trip!
